reviewText: Not sure what the reviewer "Simple" Simon's problem was;but why post a review for a dvd that isn't out yet?As for the complaints;personaly I thought the fourth season was one of the best with the return of Slade,and because it focused on Raven(who is my favorite Titan) I also love her voice actor counterpart Tara Strong who is extremely talented.Very dark storytelling,but also paired up with the same amount of humor that's to be found when watching Teen Titans.I agree that the fifth season was a bit...off... but in the grand scheme of things,Teen Titans was one of the best action cartoons of it's time and still today.My personal phillosophy:if you can nitpick a good show to death,then shut up and create one that's better.

reviewText: with better episodes and stories. Also a lot more is explained about Raven's past and why she's the way she is.  With the return also of a old Titan enemy that they all thought was long gone.  Its good to see each one of the Titans pretty much have their own episode revolving around them.  I enjoyed all of them especially the 3 part season ender revolving around a prophecy of Raven being the key that brings about the destruction of the Earth.  The Titans all band together to help bring the earth from this destruction and in the process come to a greater understanding of just what Raven's gone through since joining the Titans.It makes for an excellent season end episode and leaves it wide open for the following season with many possibilities.  Great show that parents and kids can get into and enjoy along with everyone else.

reviewText: First, let me say that the animation and concept of this show is fantastic.  A blend of the better parts of Japanese and American cartooning (although there's not much good about American cartooning anymore).  The only problem that I have with this show is that it tends to get bogged down in silly capers--never mind that one of the characters is a ticking time-bomb about to destroy the world, let's see what happens when the team gets sucked into TV land, so we can make clever in-jokes about different shows.  It was worst during season 2; 3 and 4 are really much better.And obviously, I like it well enough to have continued through four seasons so far!

reviewText: Let me begin by admitting that although I am an avid animation collector, I never considered myself much of a Teen Titans fan.  I appreciated the source material but the animated series was a bit too campy and certainly too anime-heavy.That said, I took a chance on the complete 4th season on account of the great reviews it has been receiving.  Having just completed the season last night, I must express my extreme satisfaction to this collection and the series as a whole.As others have said, the show's producers and writers have found their rhythm! The 4th season relies less upon Japanese-style animation and more on wonderful plots and character development.  The series is pretty evenly mixed between funny romps and a back-story of Raven facing her destiny.  The balance is absolutely perfect between light-hearted adventures and disturbing apocalyptic good versus evil episodes.  Also worth mentioning is the surprising return of Slade with a new look and some cool surprises.Additionally, the lighter episodes are genuinely funny as opposed to gimmicky.  Without giving too much away, the episode featuring the alien "the source" (Employee of the Month) had me laughing out loud.As a long-time DCAU aficionado, I must confess that the 4th season of Teen Titans is so impressive that I've since ordered the earlier seasons to catch up on what I've been missing.Included are the following episodes:Episode 257-494 AKA Don't Touch That DialCyborg the BarbarianBirthmarkThe QuestEmployee of the MonthTROQThe ProphecyStrandedOverdriveMother Mae-EyeThe End - Part 1The End - Part 2The End - Part 3
Title: N/A

reviewText: Teen Titans was becoming problematic by this point. The show was relying on its standard formulas a bit too much (Cyborg learning he's still human) and the intentionally offbeat "wacky" episodes had a "been there, done that" feel. It was still a fun romp for kids, but there was less for adults to latch on to. Thank god for Slade.Slade's return, under the service of the demonic Trigon, is the main story arc for this year. The five episodes make for some of the darkest storytelling in the Teen Titans' series, as Raven faces her destiny as destroyer of the world. Unfortunately the story kinda fizzles by the last episode, falling into standard plot conventions and tying things up with a neat, sugary bow. This was originally billed as the final season (hence the final 3-parter called "The End") before the show was renewed for one more. If this was the finale, I would've been very disappointed.So there's strong material here, but some of it isn't quite as satisfying as it should be. If you own the other seasons, it's still worth a look. I'm also a little annoyed that WB thought a female character couldn't carry the front dvd cover on her own, hence the recycling of Robin who already appeared on season 1.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Once again, the Teen Titans have managed to impress me with great action, color, comedy, and epicness! I was impressed how they made an " end of the world" story arc about Raven! It explains a lot about how Raven seems like a dark gloomy character. I liked how they made that story arc dark and more for adults. That is one of the ways this show manages to grab in adults, and not just kids. The other episodes are very enjoyable too. The one with going inside the TV has a lot of TV jokes and parodies, "Employee of the Month" made me laugh, and "Overdrive" has a lot of laughs too. The only 2 episodes I don't like are "Mother Mae Eye" because it is just mediocre, and "Troq" because Val- Yor is too mean. I will admit, "Troq" is one if those episodes that reflect on what anyone would feel like if they had someone who treated them like dirt. Starfire knew she could not change Val-Yor's  mind, but she had friends who stood up for her and didn't judge her cruelly. That is very mature! All in all, I really enjoy watching this DVD. It is a show that just keeps getting better every season!
summary: A Dark Intense But Very Great Season!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Robin, Raven, Beast Boy, Starfire, and Cyborg are finally back in their fourth season of their action-packed, and sometimes wacky, adventures as they battle villains and other typical teenage problems.Thirteen episodes are in this 2-disc set such as:"Cyborg the Barbarian" - Cyborg accidentally gets transported into the past and attempts to save a village in danger before he loses power."Birthmark" - Raven's having an unhappy birthday because of the ominous return of the Titans' greatest enemy: Slade."Employee of the Month" - Beast Boy gets a job at a fast-food restaurant in order to get the moped of his dreams."The Prophecy" - It all becomes clear on Slade's return when Raven tells the others a grave secret involved."Mother Mae-Eye" - A personal favorite of mine, a strange woman named Mother Mae-Eye give the Titans lots of love, care, and heaping helpings of pie.  However, her latest concoction has the Titans as the main ingredient."The End" - It's the epic three-parter where the Teen Titans save the world from Slade and his new partner-in-crime, Trigon, Raven's father.A special feature in this set is similar to the "Know Your Foes" feature in the third season.  Basically it's more secret information on the Titans' villains gallery.Though I'm still surprised that "Teen Titans" is still playing on Cartoon Network and new stories are published in "Teen Titans Go" comic books, it's great to see this cool superhero team once again.  (I wonder if there's going to be a crossover episode with Ben 10 ?  You never know.)
